thread.title: Grove City Christian Teen Killed By Brain Cancer Honored By Soccer Team
thread.title_full: Grove City Christian Teen Killed By Brain Cancer Honored By Soccer Team

title: Grove City Christian Teen Killed By Brain Cancer Honored By Soccer Team
text:
By Valencia Wicker Wednesday October 7, 2015 11:31 PM UPDATED: Wednesday October 7, 2015 11:34 PM GROVE CITY, Ohio - 
As the Grove City Christian soccer team readied themselves for a game against the Worthington Warriors, there was one jersey that stuck out like no other: number 7. 
The GCCS Eagles jersey was framed and sat in the middle of the field on an easel. 
Before the start of the game, both teams stood on either side of the memorial dedicated to the Grove City teammate who once wore it: Joshua Dick. 
Dick died in July from a massive brain tumor. Family members say his initial symptoms fit the signs of dehydration. 
“They asked him if he had a headache and he said he had a headache that was nine out of ten,” Josh’s sister Rachel Dick said. 
Rachel said Josh underwent surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible. 
“To kill the rest of it, they did chemo. They started out doing chemo and radiation and the James. From there his chemo got more intense and he had his most intense chemo just this last summer,” she said. 
Rachel says Josh kept a smile during his fight against cancer and continued to do well in school. 
“He was always super positive and played games when he had his chemo treatments. He would even bring homework,” she said. 
Josh gave cancer the same energy in the hospital as he gave soccer on the field. His goal this time lifted more than his team’s score. 
“He would call other people and make their day better even though all the stuff he was going through,” Rachel said. 
School officials hung a large number 7 with Josh’s name on it, on the fence surrounding the field. Many people cried as the Dick family unveiled the memorial. 
“I hope it's something that's actually going to make a change and when people look at it, they think of the fight that he had and the faith that he had,” Rachel said. ©2015 by 10TV.com. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. Currently in Columbus
